Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cervical Epidural Analgesia in Head and Neck Cancer Surgery

Background: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effect of cervical epidural analgesia on opioid and anesthetic requirements and stress response in head and neck cancer surgery.

Methods: Thirty patients aged 18-65 years with ASA status I or II undergoing elective head and neck cancer surgery were randomised into two groups: Group E (cervical epidural analgesia with general anesthesia) and Group G (general anesthesia alone). Randomisation was done using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sequentially numbered opaque envelopes. The primary outcome was the requirement of morphine, isoflurane, and vecuronium, measured intra-operatively. Secondary outcomes included blood glucose and serum cortisol levels measured at baseline, post-incision, and post-operatively. Blinding was not possible due to the nature of the intervention.

Results: Fifteen patients were randomised to each group, with 14 in Group E and 15 in Group G completing the study. Group E showed a significant reduction in morphine (p < 0.001), isoflurane (p = 0.004), and vecuronium (p = 0.001) requirements. Post-operative blood glucose and serum cortisol levels were significantly lower in Group E (p = 0.0153 and p = 0.0074, respectively). Adverse events included bradycardia in 6.6% and hypotension in 13.3% of Group E.

Interpretation: Cervical epidural analgesia combined with general anesthesia reduces opioid and anesthetic requirements and stress response compared to general anesthesia alone in head and neck cancer surgery.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: No financial support was reported.
